sections.heading: Who can get SSI
paragraphs: Adults and children might be eligible for SSI if they have:
Find out if you might be eligible for SSI
list_items: A disability, blindness, or are age 65 or older.

sections.heading: How much you could get
paragraphs: Your monthly payment depends on your income, living situation, things you own, and other factors.
See what can affect SSI payments

sections.heading: Report changes to your income, resources, and living situation
paragraphs: Each month, you must report your wages, other income, and changes to your resources or living arrangements.
Learn about what to report

sections.heading: Programs to get more help while on SSI
paragraphs: Explore programs, like the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and Medicaid, that help you save money and take care of basic needs while on SSI.
Learn more about these programs

subpages.title: How much you could get from SSI | SSA

sections.heading: How income affects your payment
paragraphs: For every $2 you earn from work, we reduce your SSI payment by about $1. Work includes:
For every $1 you get from non-work sources, we reduce your SSI payment by about $1. Non-work sources includes:
If you live with a spouse, their income may affect your payment.
Children on SSI who live with their parents may have their payments lowered based on their income or their parents' income.
Learn more about how income affects your payment

sections.heading: Living with others may affect your payment
paragraphs: If you live in someone else’s home and don’t pay your fair share of food and shelter costs, your SSI payment may be lowered by up to $342.33.
Learn more about how living arrangements affect your payment

sections.heading: Extra support from your state
paragraphs: Some states offer an extra payment called a “state supplement” to help with food and shelter costs. This type of payment won’t reduce your SSI.
See which states offer supplements

sections.heading: Report monthly wages and other income
paragraphs: Report your wages monthly and submit changes in other income to continue receiving accurate payments.
See how to report your income

sections.heading: Report changes to your living situation and resources
paragraphs: Your monthly payments and eligibility may be affected by changes to your resources, marital status, and living arrangement (including entering or leaving a medical facility or incarceration).
See how to report changes to your situation

subpages.title: Programs to get more help while on SSI | SSA

sections.heading: Explore other government programs
paragraphs: If you get SSI, you can usually get federal benefits like the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and state benefits like Medicaid. SNAP helps pay for food, and Medicaid helps pay doctor and hospital bills. Help from these programs won’t affect your SSI payment.
Your state might also have other programs to help you, like rent rebates and Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF).
Visit usa.gov to see what programs are available

sections.heading: Make a work or business plan
paragraphs: A Plan to Achieve Self-Support (PASS) lets you set aside money to get a new job or start a business. The money you save doesn’t count toward your SSI resource limit, and you may be eligible for a higher income limit to help you save.
Learn more about PASS

sections.heading: Save for disability-related expenses
paragraphs: If you were under age 26 when you became disabled, you can save for disability-related expenses with an Achieving a Better Life Experience (ABLE) account. The first $100,000 in an ABLE account won’t count toward your SSI resource limit.
Learn more about ABLE accounts
